creator: sonam.chauhan@ce.com.au
text:
If two HTTP Authorization managers are used in one thread group, they affect
each others settings. If seperated out by Simple Logic Controllers, they do not. 

I will attach a JMX that shows this effect. To replicate, just use on a site
that requires HTTP Basic authentication and modify the JMX to have valid and
invalid passwords (see comments in JMX attached)

Created attachment 10840
JMX illustrating this problem (as specified in initial report)
creator: sonam.chauhan@ce.com.au

text:
In my initial comment I wrote: "If seperated out by Simple Logic Controllers, [
HTTP Authorization managers work properly ]"

Actually, I did some more testing  and this does not fix the problem. Parcelling
different HTTP Authorization managers into different Simple Controllers did not
help. It seems that Authentication tokens from the second HTTP Auth manager
instance overriding the first one at runtime.

text:
A colleage reports the same problem in 'HTTP Header Manager'. He has two HTTP 
header managers in the one test plan. Changing entries in one header manager, 
changes the entries in the other header manager as well. 

This is quite a problem -- we were counting on manually setting HTTP Basic Auth 
headers (eg:  Authorization: Basic QWxhZGRpbjpvcGVuIHNlc2FtZQ==) in the HTTP 
header manager to work around the bug in the 'HTTP Authorization Manager'. 

IIRC from some (abortive) JMeter development I did before, multiple instances 
of the same test element affecting each other was a problem.
